author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
Min family, the only Chinese-Indian family who migrated to Tirupur over seven decades back, lives very much as Indians, speak fluent Tamil, eat dosas and idilis and celebrates Indian festivals.

On February 8, they, however, celebrated the Chinese New Year with fond memories with traditional fervour and following the exact rituals followed in China.

The Chinese New Year begins on the 'new moon day' between January 21 and February 20. This year it fell on February 8.

The festivities will last for 15 days ending with prayers on every day in the morning and in the night by the senior most member of the family leading the rituals.

“We never celebrate any other Chinese festival because the exact customs and traditions connected with them are not known much to this generation. My grandparents fled China like many others following the disastrous effect caused by the China-Japan war in the 1930s,” said Sebastian Leo Shaou Kang Min and his brother Stephen George Min, both doctors.Celebrations for Min family starts on the eve of the New Year with entire members, spread over three-generations, gather for a sumptuous dinner.

Even the feast have a speciality. The number of dishes will be an 'even number' as per traditions.

We had 12 dishes this time, said Dr. Sebastian Min.

For a change, the dinner had chicken soup, prawns, eggs wrapped in chicken and 'curry' made of pulses, all in Chinese style.On the New Year day, the head of the family opens the front door, the family burst crackers, and distributed sweets to neighbours and friends.
title: A nostalgic celebration
